quoteFirst: We stopped at several small villages, and at
quoteLast: reached Entre Rios, having changed mules seven times, and done the 59-1/2 miles in four hours and fifty minutes, including stoppages--pretty good work, especially as the heat during the latter portion of the journey had been as great as the cold was at the commencement.
title: A Voyage in the 'Sunbeam', Our Home on the Ocean for Eleven Months
author: Brassey, Annie, 1839-1887

quoteFirst: We then got the head from the buck Sam had killed the day before, and returned to camp
title:
Cruisings in the Cascades
A Narrative of Travel, Exploration, Amateur Photography,
Hunting, and Fishing
author: Shields, G. O. (George O.), 1846-1925

quoteFirst: , and who pompously assumed the title of ambassador. The die was cast; the two armies drew up for battle in the plain. It was
quoteTime: about eleven o'clock in the morning
quoteLast: . On the 18th of April, 1746, before close of day, the Jacobite army had ceased to exist.
title: A Popular History of England, From the Earliest Times to the Reign of Queen Victoria; Vol. IV

quoteFirst: Two days before Captain D. and I were to return to Juja we approached,
quoteTime: about eleven o'clock in the morning
quoteLast: , a long, low, rugged range of hills called Lucania. They were not very high, but bold with cliffs, buttes, and broken rocky stretches. Here we were to make our final hunt.
title: African Camp Fires
author: White, Stewart Edward, 1873-1946

quoteFirst: Having reached the anchorage off the tiny settlement on the main island of the group at
quoteLast: of March 23, 1815, the sheets of the head-sails on the _Hornet_ were let go preparatory to swinging her up into the wind and dropping her anchor. But no sooner had the sails begun to flap than the lookout announced a sail in sight, and hauling aft the sheets once more the _Hornet_ stood out to sea for a look at the stranger.
title: The history of our Navy from its origin to the present day, 1775-1897, vol. 3 (of 4)
author: Spears, John Randolph, 1850-1936

quoteFirst: Landor to be brought to Taklakot. On the evening of 7th September _Peshkár_ Kharak Sing arrived there. At
quoteLast: on the 8th September Mr. Landor, Chanden Sing, and Man Sing arrived. I took them to my tent and heard their account of what had happened.
title: In the forbidden land
author: Landor, Arnold Henry Savage, 1865-1924

quoteFirst: We were ordered to be in readiness to march at 4 o'clock this morning, but did not start till near 9 o'clock a. m.; marched until
quoteLast: , and encamped about three miles from the North Anna river; heavy artillery firing heard in the direction of the river; have not heard the result; very warm all day, but the men bear the heat grandly. General Longstreet's Corps is only about three miles ahead of us from which it would seem we are chasing him--anyway, have captured many of his stragglers.
title: Personal Recollections and Civil War Diary, 1864
author: Abbott, Lemuel Abijah, 1842-1911

quoteLast: she was in the lounge taking tea after the pleasant and refreshing custom of the country.  Mrs Cork and some gambling cronies were bridging as usual at another table, and there were various people scattered about, reading and gossiping.
title: Pink Gods and Blue Demons
author: Stockley, Cynthia, 1883-1936

quoteLast: , there came on a heavy squall from the S.E., which blew with tremendous fury for nearly an hour, accompanied with very heavy and incessant rain.
title: Two Voyages to New South Wales and Van Diemen's Land
